image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An inquiry has been announced into the state, territory and federal governments' response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: Government announces inquiry into federal, state and territory response to pandemic

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

props.synopsis: The country is transitioning through the largest building code changes in a decade. But what does this mean for home owners?

title.children: Building your dream home? Here's what you'll need to consider under new construction code changes

image.altText: A woman sits at a poker machine. Surrounding her are several large, bright and colourfully lit machines.

props.synopsis: A gambling reform advocate says she suspects people are gambling and trying to get in front of the curve when things are tough.

title.children: Queensland gambling losses climb beyond $5 billion a year

image.altText: a young woman sick with a cold sitting on a bed blowing her nose with a tissue

props.synopsis: Queensland's chief health officer says the public should be "alert but not alarmed", after a surge in Group A Streptococcus infections. Here's how to stay safe.

title.children: 'Rare' strep A infections have jumped in Queensland, with a childcare worker currently in hospital

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN, Ukraine calls for stripping of Russia's veto power

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: Jarome Luai sits on the ground

props.synopsis: Star five-eighth Jarome Luai has been cleared to return from a dislocated shoulder for Penrith's preliminary final against Melbourne.

title.children: Luai cleared to play for Panthers in prelim against Storm

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: A drone overhead shot of a dusty dig site

props.synopsis: You don't need to be a palaeontologist to dig up dinosaur bones. These volunteers are unearthing a 95-million-year-old sauropod skeleton near Winton, proving all you need is curiosity and a keen eye.

title.children: At this outback dig, volunteers with a lifelong passion for dinosaurs are 'finding new bones every day'

image.altText: Bomb remains in dirt next to small signs with skull and crossbones on them.

props.synopsis: In a letter to the US government, a UN torture expert says cluster munitions — which are prohibited by more than 100 countries — "indiscriminately and seriously injure civilians both at the time of use and in post-conflict" and should not be used.

title.children: US urged not to give Ukraine weapons which could 'remain dangerous for decades'

image.altText: Man in a suit stands for his bail hearing in front of a crowd of photograpers.

props.synopsis: Oscar Pistorius was eligible for parole in March and the double-amputee Olympic runner may have been wrongly denied early release from prison because of an error.

title.children: Oscar Pistorius may have been wrongly denied parole over error

image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: Eddie Jones looks pensive after the Wallabies lost to Fiji at the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: Retired Test winger Drew Mitchell blames veteran coach Eddie Jones for putting the Wallabies in danger of missing the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals for the first time.

title.children: Ex-Wallaby unloads expletive-loaded criticism on Eddie Jones as World Cup campaign hangs by a thread

image.altText: Trees in Beerwah stand burnt and blacked from fire

props.synopsis: Queensland Ambulance Service supervisor Mitch Ware says paramedics are prepared for an "early taste" of El Niño.

title.children: Queensland on bushfire and heat alert with 'early taste' of El Niño

image.altText: A black and white portrait of a young man in a cowboy outfit.

props.synopsis: Will Reynolds was a beach-loving Sydney teenager when a gap year on a Top End cattle station changed his life and set him on a high-stakes career path as a rodeo rider.

title.children: 'I just ticked every box and gave it a crack': How a Sydney surfer became a US cowboy

image.altText: Collingwood's Mason Cox leaps high and takes the ball in one hand at a contest as players stand around.

props.synopsis: The AFL's preliminary finals weekend pits the league's two most consistent teams of the year — Collingwood and Brisbane — with the most in-form challengers — GWS and Carlton. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson break down how the games will be won and lost.

title.children: The leaders or the challengers? How two massive AFL preliminary finals will be decided

image.altText: A composite image of Peter Hudson on the left and Magenta Marshall on the right.

props.synopsis: The WA Liberal Party's candidate in the Rockingham by-election apologises for asking a constituent to question his opponent whether she would resign from parliament if she fell pregnant.

title.children: Scheme to ask by-election rival about her pregnancy plans ends in 'regret' from Liberal candidate

image.altText: A man's hands

props.synopsis: Peter says when he spoke up about what his primary school teacher had done decades before, he smiled for the first time in years. He's one of a growing number of men coming forward to get help, according to a WA support service.

title.children: More male survivors of sexual assault are seeking help — but specialised support services are hard to find

image.altText: The silhouette of a power station is seen against the sky in the early evening, with thick smoke billowing from three towers.

props.synopsis: There are growing safety concerns at Yallourn Power Station in Victoria, one of Australia's biggest coal-fired power plants. Experts say that could be bad news heading into a long, hot summer.

title.children: Dark clouds gather over one of Australia's biggest coal plants as El Niño heats the land

image.altText: The six politicians stand in front of the US Capitol building.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: Julian Assange unites cross-party delegation in Washington to push for WikiLeaks founder's freedom

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: George RR Martin

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin sues OpenAI for 'systematic theft', Australia urges US to let Julian Assange walk free. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Reserve Bank Governor Ian Macfarlane makes a point

props.synopsis: The proposed move to establish a separate body within the Reserve Bank to make interest rates decisions in future, was "very bad policy" and "a leap of faith" which would undermine the authority of the governor, according to former governor Ian Macfarlane.

title.children: 'Very bad policy': Former RBA governor calls for discussions around bank's changes

image.altText: A small brown Malleefowl chick ina mans hands

props.synopsis: The chicken-sized, chick-abandoning birds have one thing in common with the tiny bush town trying to save them.

title.children: Inside the fight to save a little town and its vulnerable bird population

image.altText: A night vision image of a pet cat carrying native prey in it's mouth.

props.synopsis: An ecologist warns pet owners to keep predatory animals secure, after a cat is spotted on the Yorke Peninsula in South Australia posing a threat to recently reintroduced brush-tailed bettongs.

title.children: Pet cat caught on camera carrying native prey in national park home to precious endangered bettong colony

image.altText: a man in an office with documents

props.synopsis: Former chair of the ACCC to oversee an inquiry into Price Gouging and Unfair Pricing Practices, while a fall on Wall Street sends Australian stocks lower today. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: Former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US Fed holds interest rates steady, ASX falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: My colleague Peter Ryan had a one on one interview with Qantas chairman Richard Goyder on The World Today. In his first broadcast interview since the ACCC alleged Qantas sold fares for cancelled flights, Mr Goyder conceded big mistakes were made but says new chief executive Vanessa Hudson is preparing to mediate with 1700 ground staff who were unlawfully sacked. Mr Goyder told the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan he's been busy meeting with major investors to win back trust and confidence. Mr Goyder is dealing with fallout on a number of fronts: •	the ACCC's allegations that Qantas sold fares for flights that didn't exist or had been cancelled •	last week's High Court ruling that 1700 Qantas ground staff were unlawfully sacked at the height of the pandemic •	the potential clawing back of Alan Joyce's pay (if the ACCC's allegations are proven the former Qantas boss could lose as much as $14.4million So with Alan Joyce "gone", the pressure isn't easing and in his first broadcast interview about the crisis, Richard Goyder is adamant about rolling with the turbulence for the long haul. You can listen to the interview via Peter's Twitter/X
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder is refusing to quit

children.content: had a one on one interview with
alleged Qantas sold fares for cancelled flights,
Mr Goyder conceded big mistakes were made
Vanessa Hudson is preparing to mediate with 1700 ground staff
Mr Goyder told the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan he's been busy meeting with major investors to win back trust and confidence.
Mr Goyder is dealing with fallout on a number of fronts:
•	the ACCC's allegations that Qantas sold fares for flights that didn't exist or had been cancelled
•	last week's High Court ruling that 1700 Qantas ground staff were unlawfully sacked at the height of the pandemic
•	the potential clawing back of Alan Joyce's pay (if the ACCC's allegations are proven the former Qantas boss could lose as much as $14.4million
So with Alan Joyce "gone", the pressure isn't easing and in his first broadcast interview about the crisis, Richard Goyder is adamant about rolling with the turbulence for the long haul.
You can listen to the interview via Peter's Twitter/X

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mike McNess has told the inquiry Qantas airfares have jumped 32 per cent since pre-COVID levels. "Paying a third more for a ticket wouldn't be justified even if standards had improved. "When safety and services have nosedived, workers have been illegality outsourced and wages of those that remain have been slashed, passengers should not be seeing increases to ticket prices, these prices should be halved."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Calls for Qantas ticket prices to be cheaper, not more expensive

children.content: jumped 32 per cent since pre-COVID levels.

"When safety and services have nosedived, workers have been illegality outsourced and wages of those that remain have been slashed, passengers should not be seeing increases to ticket prices,

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The TWU's, Mike McNess is speaking about Qantas to the price gouging inquiry taking place in Melbourne today. Meantime, Qantas Chairman Richard Goyder has just confirmed with my colleague Peter Ryan that he will front Senate inquiry into aviation next week. We'll bring you a bit more on that shortly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas Chairman Richard Goyder will front Senate inquiry next week

children.content: Mike McNess is speaking about Qantas to the price gouging inquiry taking place in Melbourne today.
has just confirmed with my colleague Peter Ryan that
he will front Senate inquiry into aviation next week

image.altText: The silhouette of a firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning high into trees.

props.synopsis: Catastrophic fire danger warnings have been issued in parts of Australia already as it enters a hotter and drier than average climate pattern. If the fire season has taken you by surprise, here's a reminder of how the warning system works.

title.children: What makes a bushfire alert 'catastrophic', and how should you respond?

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: A Pizza Hut sign.

props.synopsis: Pizza Hut Australia says the data breach only impacted the Australian market and does not affect Pizza Hut's operations in any other country.

title.children: Nearly 200k Pizza Hut customers affected by cyber hack

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

props.synopsis: Former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce was paid $21.4 million in the last financial year, but more than half could be subjected to a clawback by the airline's board.

title.children: Qantas paid former CEO Alan Joyce $21.4 million last financial year

image.altText: Wind turbines are set to dot the landscape in Victoria's west

props.synopsis: Some experts are warning Australia's ambitions to have zero carbon emissions by 2050 need to be scaled up dramatically.

title.children: Reaching net zero by 2035 would take a 'gargantuan' effort. But these experts say our current 2050 target is just too far away

image.altText: Researcher digging things from underground.

props.synopsis: Archaeologists say they have unearthed the oldest wooden structure ever discovered, near Zambia's Kalambo Falls.

title.children: Wooden structure from before time of homo sapiens found in Zambia

image.altText: Oscar Piastri gives a thumbs up

props.synopsis: Australia's Oscar Piastri cements his place at McLaren alongside Lando Norris as he targets future F1 success.

title.children: Piastri extends McLaren F1 deal, takes veiled shot at Alpine

image.altText: young woman address media

props.synopsis: The inquest is examining the disappearance of Tina Louise Greer, who went missing from her Beechmont home in the Gold Coast hinterland in 2012.

title.children: 'I refuse to be silenced': Daughter of suspected murder victim Tina Greer speaks out over 'systematic failures'
